entry.title: Combined summary - Why Satoshi's temporary anti-spam measure isn't temporary
entry.summary: The email conversation revolves around the scalability of Bitcoin. Pieter Wuille suggests that the block size should be gradually scaled as technology grows. However, Gavin Andresen disagrees with this proposal, citing the current miners' reluctance to validate blocks. Instead, he proposes deploying Blockstream Elements on the main network for scalability work. He also emphasizes that sidechains are a mechanism for experimentation and increasing the blockchain size has better security tradeoffs than moving coins to a sidechain. Owen disagrees with Mike Hearn's analysis, stating that Bitcoin is more than just a payment system. It offers sound money, censorship resistance, personal control over money, programmable money, and more. Additionally, Bitcoin has an important social/political promise. Mike Hearn argues that if Bitcoin's security properties are not strong enough, then advanced tools cannot be built for it. The email conversation ends with a discussion about Satoshi's words, where Mike Hearn accuses Gregory Maxwell of misleading him.In the email exchange between Greg Maxwell and Mike Hearn, Maxwell accuses Hearn of distorting Bitcoin's history in his arguments for increasing the block size limit. He believes that doing so will lead to centralization, undermining the decentralized nature of Bitcoin. Maxwell argues that Bitcoin's unique value lies in its ability to accommodate different preferences under one tent. He also points out that Satoshi Nakamoto envisioned a future where only miners ran nodes, but this should not be used as an argument for centralization. The email exchange includes discussions on smart contracts, off-chain systems, SPV wallets, and the potential negative outcomes of blindly pumping for growth without taking responsibility for the system's resource consumption and potential failure. The creator of Bitcoin had a clear understanding that putting every consensus decision into one system would not be scalable. It was also well understood that users of Bitcoin would wish to protect its decentralization by limiting the size of the chain to keep it verifiable on small devices. Some parties engaging in mining found it to be highly profitable, even including losses from issues. The blockchain provides utility at every size, but any finite size will permit some use cases and not others. Available space should grow with technology to keep the relative costs to the ecosystem for maintaining a decentralized system constant. Bitcoin's advantage over other systems does not lie in scalability. Making controversial changes to the network, and not wanting to face the reality that block chain space is a finite resource, is a huge threat to Bitcoin's usefulness in the long term. It would be best to scale the block size gradually over time according to technological growth.
